statements.name: PROC GKPI

arguments.name: MODE=
arguments.description: specifies the display mode of KPI chart images.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: creates a two-dimensional image.

arguments.name: MODERN
arguments.description: creates an image with a streamlined appearance.

arguments.name: RAISED
arguments.description: creates a three-dimensional version of the basic KPI.

statements.name: DIAL
statements.description: Creates a chart in the dial display type.

arguments.name: ACTUAL=
arguments.description: specifies the actual value of the key performance indicator (KPI). The actual data value can fall outside the bounds specified with the BOUNDS= option, but the GKPI procedure displays that actual value indicator at the outermost edge of the KPI chart.

arguments.name: BOUNDS=
arguments.description: specifies a list of defined boundary values. The values can be negative or positive, but you must specify the list in either ascending or descending order. Separate each boundary value with a blank space.

arguments.name: ACTIVECOLORS=
arguments.description: specifies the list of active colors for each qualitative range.

arguments.name: AFONT=
arguments.description: specifies the name, color, and text height for the font used for the actual KPI value label.

arguments.name: AVALUE
arguments.description: specifies to display the actual KPI value label.

arguments.name: BFONT=
arguments.description: specifies the name, color, and text height of the font used for the boundary and tick mark values.

arguments.name: BVALUE
arguments.description: specifies to display the boundary values.

arguments.name: COLORS=
arguments.description: specifies the list of inactive colors for each qualitative range.

arguments.name: DESCRIPTION=
arguments.description: specifies the description of the output.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS format for the boundary and actual values.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a label for the graphic.

arguments.name: LFONT=
arguments.description: specifies the name, color, text height and justification of the font to use for the label that is specified by the LABEL= option.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: adds a drill-down link to the KPI chart.

arguments.name: LOWBOUNDARY
arguments.description: specifies that the KPI chart displays as if the KPI value falls in the lower range when the actual KPI value falls directly on a range boundary.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the graphics output file.

arguments.name: NOAVALUE
arguments.description: specifies not to display the actual KPI value label.

arguments.name: NOBVALUE
arguments.description: specifies not to display the boundary values.

arguments.name: NOLOWBOUNDARY
arguments.description: specifies that the KPI chart displays as if the KPI value falls in the upper range when the actual KPI value falls directly on a range boundary.

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: specifies the numeric value of the target key performance indicator.

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: specifies the font name. You can specify only system fonts (such as TrueType and UNIX system fonts), not SAS/GRAPH fonts. For more information, see .

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the text color. You can specify the color in any of the color-naming schemes recognized by SAS/GRAPH.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the font height in units. You can specify the text height in units of points (PT), centimeters (CM), inches (IN), or percentage of the graphics output area (PCT).

arguments.name: JUSTIFICATION=
arguments.description: specifies whether the text is left-justified, centered, or right-justified within the graphics output area. You can specify LEFT, RIGHT, or CENTER.

statements.name: HBULLET
statements.description: Creates a chart in the horizontal bullet display type.

statements.name: QUIT
statements.description: Executes any statements that have not executed and ends the procedure step.
